eu.excitement.entailment.core.component.syntacticknowledge

Class SyntacticRule<I,S extends AbstractNode<I,S>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • eu.excitement.entailment.core.component.syntacticknowledge.SyntacticRule<I,S>
  • Type Parameters:
    I - The information type of the tree-nodes, e.g. Info. See AbstractNode.
    S - The rule's nodes, e.g. BasicNode. See AbstractNode.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class SyntacticRule<I,S extends AbstractNode<I,S>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    [DELETEME_LATER: imported and extended from BIUTEE 2.4.1 "rule", but somewhat different. 1) "relation" added. 2) introduction removed.(NEED2TALK?)] Some entailment relationships cannot be described well at the lexical level, but require access to the syntactic level. Examples include changes of verb voice, changes in a predicate's argument structure, or proper paraphrase. In the EXCITEMENT platform, we call syntactic level knowledge syntactic rules, and a collection of such rules with standard access methods a syntactic rulebase. Similar to lexical rules, syntactic rules also have two sides (LHS and RHS) and define the relationship between the them (for example, LHS entails RHS, or LHS does not entail RHS). Unlike in the case of lexical knowledge, each side (LHS / RHS) is defined as a partial parse tree. (e.g. that of BasicNode) *

    A Rule is:

    1. left hand side
    2. right hand side
    3. a mapping from (part of) the left hand nodes to the right hand side nodes.

    Note that Rule does not implement equals() and hashCode(). I.e. each rule is unique in the system.

    See Also:
